moves.5. e4 Bb4 6. Bxc4 Nge7 7. O-O O-O: Both me and my opponent complete our King-side development.
moves.8. Bg5 Bxc3 9. bxc3 h6 10. Bh4: I try to draw my opponent into playing P-KN4, breaking the pin but opening up his castled position. But it doesn't work.
moves.10... Qd7 11. Bb5: I always try to pin enemy pieces when i can. It restricts their options.
moves.11... a6 12. Ne5 Qd6 13. Bxc6 Nxc6: So far the game has remained even.
moves.14. f4 Nxe5 15. fxe5 Qc6: I have to be careful not to lose a Pawn in the center. The doubled KP is a weakness.
moves.16. Qd3 a5 17. Be1: I defend the base of my Pawn chain.
moves.17... b6: I overlook the effect of this move.
moves.18. Bd2 Ba6: Nicely played. Now I lose the Exchange. 18 Q-K3 was the move I should have played to avoid it.
moves.19... Bxf1 20. Rxf1 Qe8: A mistake. Ahead in material, my opponent should be advancing instead of retreating.
moves.21. Qg3: Now I must be aggressive. i try hereabouts to formulate a mating attack. I am aiming, if my opponent permits, to play 22 BxP and follow up with 23 QxP mate.
moves.21... Kh8 22. Rf4 f6 23. Rh4: Hoping my opponent would think the KRP is sufficiently guarded. I try for 24 BxP PxB 25 RxP mate.
moves.23... h5 24. Qf3: My goal now is to win back the material and press the attack. I threaten 25 RxP ch.
moves.24... g6: Now the KBP is insufficiently guarded, enabling me to create a passed Pawn and undouble my Pawns.
moves.25. exf6 Rf7 26. e5: A protected passed Pawn. Now I can fix my opponent's pieces.
moves.29... Rg8 30. h4: Locking the position. Neither side can accomplish much, and I'm happy to take a draw given that I'm still behind in material.
